Legal_Issue: Entitlement to a maritime lien for bunker fuel supplied to the vessel
Procedural_Stage: Action in rem, vessel arrest, court adjudication
Evidence_Assessment: Supply of bunkers based on contract with bareboat charterer; no effective notice rebutting authority
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish valid supply and authority of charterer
Credibility_Factor: Presumption of authority of bareboat charterer under U.S. law
Legal_Rule: Supplier of necessaries ordered by authorized person has maritime lien on vessel
Standard_of_Review: Application of statutory interpretation and contractual choice of law
Procedural_Issue: Enforceability of choice of law clause favoring U.S. law
Grounds_for_Claim: Unpaid supply of bunker fuel to the ship
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Proper service and opportunity to contest claim
Key_Evidence_Considered: Contract between plaintiff and bareboat charterer; lack of notice against charterer's authority
Legal_Framework: U.S. Maritime Law, international shipping practices
Applicant_Challenge: Establishing entitlement to maritime lien despite non-owner contracting party
Court_Result: Maritime lien granted; defendants ordered to pay Cdn $123,914.74 plus interest
Defendant_Response: No effective rebuttal of charterer’s authority or challenge to choice of law
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence: supply contract, invoices, charter agreement
Remedy_Requested: Payment for unpaid bunker fuel and recognition of maritime lien
Outcome: Plaintiff successful; lien enforced; payment awarded
Remedy_Sought: Monetary compensation and in rem enforcement via vessel arrest
Outcome_of_Review: Affirmation of maritime lien under U.S. law
Jurisdiction: U.S. law applied; enforcement in Canada via vessel arrest
Governing_Rule: Maritime Lien under U.S. law for necessaries supplied by authorized party
